events.title: Stone Age
events.desc: Lasting for over 3 million years, the Stone Age began with the first stone tools and ended at different times regionally with the adoption of metallurgy. The vast majority occurred before the Holocene Era.

events.title: Peopling of Sahul (Australia)
events.desc: Humans cross the Wallace Line to colonize Australia, New Guinea, and Tasmania‚Äîthe earliest evidence of advanced maritime capability. Required open-ocean voyages and represents the oldest continuous culture on Earth. Archaeological and genetic dating differ by 15,000 years, an active scientific debate.

events.title: Holocene Epoch Begins
events.desc: The geological epoch marking the end of the last Ice Age and the start of the current warm interval. Begins approximately 11,700 years before present and coincides with major human transitions to sedentism and agriculture.

events.title: Neolithic Revolution Begins
events.desc: End of the Ice Age. Humans transition to agriculture, domesticate animals, and settle permanently in the Fertile Crescent.

events.title: Domestication of Sheep
events.desc: Sheep become among the earliest domesticated livestock animals in Mesopotamia, used for meat, milk, and later wool.

events.title: G√∂bekli Tepe
events.desc: Massive stone temple complex built in modern Turkey‚Äîpredating pottery, metallurgy, and the wheel. The world's oldest known temple.

events.title: First Cereal Cultivation
events.desc: Wild wheat and barley are first cultivated in the Fertile Crescent. They may initially have been used for gruel or fermented beverages before widespread bread production.

events.title: Domestication of Pigs
events.desc: Pigs domesticated independently in Anatolia and China. Efficient converters of scraps to protein.

events.title: Jericho Settlement
events.desc: One of humanity's first permanent settlements builds defensive walls and a tower.

events.title: Domestication of Cattle
events.desc: Aurochs domesticated in the Near East and South Asia. Cattle provide meat, milk, leather, and labor.

events.title: 8.2 Kiloyear Event
events.desc: Most severe climate event of the Holocene. Sudden cooling occurred approximately 8,200 years ago (around 3800 HE), likely caused by the catastrophic drainage of glacial Lake Agassiz into the North Atlantic.

events.title: Pottery Invented (and earlier regional origins)
events.desc: Fired clay pottery emerges independently in multiple regions. While pottery becomes widespread in the Near East after c. 2000 HE, the earliest known pottery fragments have been found in East Asia (Xianrendong, China) with contexts dated to roughly 19,000‚Äì20,000 years before present.

events.title: √áatalh√∂y√ºk
events.desc: One of the world's first proto-cities in Anatolia. Up to 10,000 residents live in densely packed mudbrick houses entered through rooftop holes.

events.title: 'Ain Ghazal Settlement
events.desc: One of the largest Neolithic settlements, near modern Amman, Jordan. Famous for its plaster statues and ancestor worship practices.

events.title: Wheel Invented
events.desc: The earliest archaeological evidence of wheeled vehicles and potter‚Äôs wheels appears in Mesopotamia, revolutionizing transportation and manufacturing.

events.title: Copper Smelting Begins
events.desc: Humans learn to extract copper from ore using fire. The Chalcolithic (Copper Age) begins, ending the Stone Age.

events.title: Bantu Expansion
events.desc: The most significant demographic event in African prehistory. Bantu-speaking peoples spread from West Africa (modern Nigeria/Cameroon) across sub-Saharan Africa, carrying agriculture and later iron-working. By 10500 HE they reached South Africa, transforming the continent's linguistic and genetic landscape.

events.title: 4.2 Kiloyear Event
events.desc: Severe aridification event occurring approximately 4,200 years ago (around 7800 HE). Contributed to the collapse of the Egyptian Old Kingdom and the Akkadian Empire.

events.title: Domestication of the Horse
events.desc: Horses are first managed on the Eurasian steppes. Early Botai horses (~6500 HE) differ genetically from later domestic lineages that spread widely after ~7800 HE, revolutionizing transportation, warfare, and communication.

events.title: Bronze Age
events.desc: Copper-tin alloy creates bronze‚Äîharder than copper alone. Weapons, tools, and trade networks transform society.

events.title: Indus Valley Civilization
events.desc: One of the three cradles of civilization. Harappa and Mohenjo-daro featured advanced urban planning, standardized weights, and sophisticated drainage systems.

events.title: Newgrange
events.desc: Massive prehistoric monument built in Ireland. The passage tomb is older than Stonehenge and the Egyptian pyramids, aligned to the winter solstice sunrise.

events.title: Stonehenge
events.desc: Iconic prehistoric monument built on Salisbury Plain, England. Purpose debated‚Äîlikely astronomical observatory and ceremonial site.

events.title: First Cities in Mesopotamia
events.desc: Uruk, Ur, and Eridu emerge in southern Iraq. Urban planning, specialized labor, and social hierarchy develop.

events.title: Caral-Supe Civilization
events.desc: The oldest civilization in the Americas, flourishing in coastal Peru. Achieved monumental architecture and urban complexity without pottery or grain agriculture, relying on maritime resources and cotton trade. Developed quipu record-keeping 4,000 years before the Inca.

events.title: Invention of Writing
events.desc: Cuneiform in Sumer, hieroglyphs in Egypt. History begins‚Äîeverything before is "prehistory."

events.title: Ancient Egypt
events.desc: One of the longest-lasting civilizations. Pyramids, hieroglyphs, pharaohs, and the Nile defined 3,000 years of history.

events.title: Minoan Civilization
events.desc: Bronze Age civilization on Crete and other Aegean islands. Built elaborate palaces at Knossos, developed Linear A script, and influenced Greek mythology.

events.title: Great Pyramid of Giza
events.desc: Built for Pharaoh Khufu. Tallest structure on Earth for 3,800 years.

events.title: Maya Preclassic Period
events.desc: Maya civilization emerges in Mesoamerica. First cities, monumental architecture, and hieroglyphic writing develop.

events.title: Abraham
events.desc: Traditional date for the patriarch Abraham, father of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

events.title: Code of Hammurabi
events.desc: One of the oldest deciphered legal codes. "An eye for an eye" enters human thought.

events.title: Moses and the Exodus
events.desc: Traditional date for Moses leading the Israelites out of Egypt. The Ten Commandments given.

events.title: Iron Age (Near East)
events.desc: Iron replaces bronze as the dominant metal in the Near East and Mediterranean. New weapons and tools enable larger empires and transform warfare. Transitions into Classical Antiquity; in Northern Europe, the Iron Age continues until c. 10800 HE.

events.title: Classical Antiquity
events.desc: Era of ancient Greece and Rome. Philosophy, democracy, republican government, and classical art flourish. Ends with the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

events.title: King David
events.desc: David becomes King of Israel, uniting the tribes. Jerusalem becomes the capital.

events.title: Polynesian Expansion
events.desc: Humanity's greatest feat of open-ocean navigation. Polynesian voyagers settle Hawaii, Easter Island, and New Zealand across thousands of miles of Pacific using stars, currents, and wave patterns.

events.title: Solomon's Temple Built
events.desc: King Solomon completes the First Temple in Jerusalem, the holiest site in Judaism.

events.title: Neo-Assyrian Empire
events.desc: A powerful imperial state dominating the Near East, noted for its military organization, administration, and imperial scale.

events.title: Athenian Democracy Emerges
events.desc: Reforms of Cleisthenes establish one of the earliest known large-scale democratic systems, influencing later political thought, philosophy, and civic life.

events.title: Axial Age
events.desc: Parallel intellectual revolutions across Eurasia give rise to transformative moral and religious traditions. Confucianism and Taoism in China, Buddhism and Jainism in India, Zoroastrianism in Persia, and Greek philosophy in the Mediterranean. These traditions emphasize universal ethics and reshape worldviews across civilizations.

events.title: First Olympic Games
events.desc: Traditional date for the first Olympic Games at Olympia, Greece. Athletic competition becomes sacred.

events.title: Founding of Rome
events.desc: Traditional date for the founding of Rome by Romulus. A small village destined to rule the world.

events.title: Buddha (Siddhartha Gautama)
events.desc: Founder of Buddhism born in Lumbini, Nepal. His teachings on suffering and enlightenment spread across Asia.

events.title: Confucius
events.desc: Kong Qiu born in Lu, China. His teachings will shape Chinese civilization for millennia.

events.title: Roman Republic Founded
events.desc: Rome overthrows its kings. The Republic will shape governance for millennia.

events.title: Battle of Marathon
events.desc: Athens defeats Persian invasion. The runner Pheidippides inspires the modern marathon.

events.title: Socrates
events.desc: The father of Western philosophy born in Athens. Will teach Plato and die for his beliefs.

events.title: Parthenon Completed
events.desc: Athens completes the Parthenon, temple to Athena. Peak of Classical Greek architecture.

events.title: Trial of Socrates
events.desc: Socrates drinks hemlock after being condemned for corrupting Athens' youth. Philosophy's first martyr.

events.title: Aristotle
events.desc: The polymath who will tutor Alexander the Great and systematize Western knowledge.

events.title: Alexander's Empire
events.desc: Conquers from Greece to India in 13 years. Hellenistic culture spreads worldwide.

events.title: Maurya Empire
events.desc: First empire to unify most of the Indian subcontinent. Emperor Ashoka's conversion to Buddhism led to edicts promoting religious tolerance and non-violence.

events.title: Library of Alexandria Founded
events.desc: One of the largest and most significant libraries of the ancient world. Center of classical learning under the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt.

events.title: Eratosthenes
events.desc: Greek polymath who calculated Earth's circumference with remarkable accuracy using shadows and geometry.

events.title: Unification of China
events.desc: Qin Shi Huang conquers the Warring States, creating the first unified Chinese empire and establishing the imperial system.

events.title: Great Wall Construction Begins
events.desc: Qin Shi Huang begins the Great Wall, connecting existing fortifications to protect against northern invasions.

events.title: Han Dynasty
events.desc: One of China's greatest dynasties. Paper invented, Silk Road flourishes.

events.title: Silk Road
events.desc: Network of trade routes connecting East Asia to the Mediterranean. Silk, spices, ideas, religions, and technologies flow between civilizations for over 1,500 years.

events.title: Teotihuacan
events.desc: One of the largest cities in the ancient world with 125,000 residents. Its massive pyramids and urban grid predated and influenced later Mesoamerican civilizations including the Aztecs.

events.title: January 1 Becomes New Year's Day
events.desc: Roman consuls begin taking office on January 1 to respond to a rebellion in Hispania, establishing the date as the start of the civil year.

events.title: Spartacus Rebellion
events.desc: Gladiator Spartacus leads history's most famous slave revolt against Rome.

events.title: Cleopatra
events.desc: Last pharaoh of Egypt. Her death marks Egypt becoming a Roman province.

events.title: Julius Caesar Assassinated
events.desc: "Et tu, Brute?" Caesar murdered by senators on the Ides of March. Republic dies with him.

events.title: Roman Empire
events.desc: From Augustus to the fall. At its peak, ruled 70 million people across three continents.

events.title: Jesus of Nazareth
events.desc: Central figure of Christianity. His life and teachings became the foundation of the world's largest religion.

events.title: Year One (CE/AD)
events.desc: The Gregorian calendar's anchor point. Calculated (with some error) as the birth year of Jesus.

events.title: Crucifixion of Jesus
events.desc: Jesus crucified in Jerusalem under Pontius Pilate. Christians believe he rose three days later.

events.title: Eruption of Vesuvius
events.desc: Mount Vesuvius buries Pompeii and Herculaneum. Preserved forever in volcanic ash.

events.title: Kingdom of Aksum
events.desc: Ethiopian empire and one of the four great powers of the ancient world. First major empire to adopt Christianity as state religion, predating Rome's conversion.

events.title: Indian Ocean Trade Network
events.desc: Maritime trade routes connecting East Africa, Arabia, India, Southeast Asia, and China. Spread goods, religions, and ideas across the hemisphere for over a millennium.

events.title: Classic Maya Period
events.desc: Golden age of Maya civilization. 40+ city-states including Tikal, Palenque, and Cop√°n. Advanced astronomy, mathematics, and the Long Count calendar.

events.title: Edict of Milan
events.desc: Constantine legalizes Christianity throughout the Roman Empire. Faith goes mainstream.

events.title: Gupta Empire
events.desc: India's Golden Age. The concept of zero, decimal system, and major advances in astronomy, medicine, mathematics, and Sanskrit literature flourish.

events.title: Fall of Rome
events.desc: Western Roman Empire collapses. Europe enters the Middle Ages.

events.title: Middle Ages
events.desc: Medieval Europe. Feudalism, castles, crusades, and the slow rebuilding of civilization.

events.title: Invention of Zero
events.desc: Indian mathematicians develop zero as both a placeholder and a number. This revolutionary concept enables modern mathematics, science, and eventually computing.

events.title: Modern Age
events.desc: From the Renaissance to the present. Characterized by nation-states, global exploration, scientific revolution, industrialization, and rapid technological change. Some divide further into Early Modern, Industrial, Atomic, and Digital ages.

events.title: Global Spread of Capitalism and Empire
events.desc: European colonial empires and capitalist trade networks expand worldwide. Chartered companies (British and Dutch East India Companies) monopolize trade across Asia, Africa, and the Americas. By the 19th century, industrial capitalism establishes global economic domination, laying foundations for modern globalization.

events.title: Plague of Justinian
events.desc: First bubonic plague pandemic. Kills up to 50 million‚Äîpossibly half of Europe's population.

events.title: Muhammad
events.desc: Prophet of Islam born in Mecca. Will unite Arabia and found the world's second-largest religion.

events.title: Hijra - Islamic Calendar Begins
events.desc: Muhammad's migration from Mecca to Medina. Year One of the Islamic calendar.

events.title: Islamic Golden Age
events.desc: Era of cultural, scientific, and economic flourishing in the Islamic world. Preservation of Greek knowledge, advances in mathematics, astronomy, medicine, and philosophy.

events.title: Viking Age
events.desc: Scandinavian seafarers explore, trade, and raid across Europe, reaching Iceland, Greenland, and North America centuries before Columbus.

events.title: Charlemagne Crowned Emperor
events.desc: Pope crowns Charlemagne Emperor of the Romans. Holy Roman Empire begins.

events.title: Khmer Empire
events.desc: Southeast Asia's dominant empire, centered in modern Cambodia. Built Angkor Wat, the largest religious monument ever constructed, and an advanced hydraulic civilization.

events.title: Classic Maya Collapse
events.desc: Major city-states abandoned over decades. Drought, warfare, and deforestation devastate the southern lowlands. Civilization shifts north to Yucat√°n.

events.title: Medieval Warm Period
events.desc: Climate similar to modern times. Vikings colonize Greenland, agriculture expands northward, and European population booms.

events.title: Norman Conquest of England
events.desc: William the Conqueror defeats Harold at Hastings. English history forever changed.

events.title: Cahokia
events.desc: The largest pre-Columbian city north of Mexico, near modern St. Louis. At its peak around 11100 HE, housed 10,000-20,000 people‚Äîrivaling contemporary London. Monks Mound, a 100-foot earthen pyramid, required moving 22 million cubic feet of earth without wheels or draft animals.

events.title: First Crusade
events.desc: Christian armies capture Jerusalem. Two centuries of religious warfare begin.

events.title: Great Zimbabwe
events.desc: Massive stone city in southern Africa and center of a wealthy trading empire. Connected the African interior to Indian Ocean trade networks, exporting gold and ivory.

events.title: Genghis Khan
events.desc: Tem√ºjin born on the Mongolian steppe. Will build the largest contiguous empire in history.

events.title: Mongol Empire
events.desc: Largest contiguous land empire ever. From Korea to Poland under one rule.

events.title: Magna Carta
events.desc: English nobles force King John to sign‚Äîfoundation of constitutional law.

events.title: Dante Alighieri
events.desc: Author of the Divine Comedy. Father of the Italian language.

events.title: Renaissance
events.desc: Rebirth of art, science, and humanism. Da Vinci, Michelangelo, and the printing press.

events.title: Little Ice Age
events.desc: Coldest period of the past two millennia. Rivers freeze, crops fail, glaciers advance. Ends with the Industrial Revolution.

events.title: Mansa Musa's Pilgrimage
events.desc: The Emperor of Mali makes his pilgrimage to Mecca, showcasing the immense wealth of West Africa to the world.

events.title: Black Death
events.desc: Bubonic plague kills 75-200 million people across Eurasia‚Äîup to 60% of Europe's population. Society transformed.

events.title: Gutenberg's Press
events.desc: Movable type printing spreads knowledge faster than ever before.

events.title: Leonardo da Vinci
events.desc: The ultimate Renaissance man. Painter, inventor, scientist, and visionary.

events.title: Fall of Constantinople
events.desc: Ottoman Turks conquer the Byzantine capital. End of the Roman Empire after 1,500 years.

events.title: Aztec Empire
events.desc: Dominant alliance in central Mexico. Built Tenochtitlan, one of the world's largest cities, before falling to Spanish conquistadors.

events.title: Inca Empire
events.desc: The largest empire in pre-Columbian America, engineering a vast road network and monuments like Machu Picchu in the Andes.

events.title: Columbus Reaches Americas
events.desc: European contact with the "New World." Global exchange‚Äîand exploitation‚Äîbegins.

events.title: Columbian Exchange
events.desc: Massive exchange of plants, animals, people, and pathogens between the Americas and Afro-Eurasia. Old World diseases devastated indigenous populations (up to 90% mortality). New World crops (maize, potatoes, tomatoes) spread globally, transforming agriculture, diets, and demographics worldwide.

events.title: Protestant Reformation
events.desc: Martin Luther posts 95 Theses. Christianity splits, religious wars follow.

events.title: Transatlantic Slave Trade
events.desc: Forced migration of 12.5 million Africans to the Americas. Fundamental driver of the modern Atlantic economy, shaping demographics, culture, and politics across four continents. One of history's greatest crimes against humanity.

events.title: Copernican Revolution
events.desc: Copernicus publishes heliocentric theory. Earth is not the center of the universe.

events.title: William Shakespeare
events.desc: The Bard of Avon. Wrote the most influential works in English literature.

events.title: Galileo Galilei
events.desc: Father of modern science. Confirmed Copernicus and faced the Inquisition.

events.title: Mayflower Landing
events.desc: Pilgrims land at Plymouth Rock. English colonization of North America begins in earnest.

events.title: Newton's Principia
events.desc: Isaac Newton publishes laws of motion and gravity. Modern physics is born.

events.title: Industrial Revolution
events.desc: Steam, factories, railways. More change in 100 years than the previous 10,000.

events.title: American Revolutionary War
events.desc: Thirteen colonies fight for independence from Britain. Birth of the United States.

events.title: American Independence
events.desc: Declaration signed. Democratic self-governance becomes reality.

events.title: French Revolution
events.desc: Monarchy overthrown. Liberty, equality, fraternity reshape political thought.

events.title: Haitian Revolution
events.desc: The only successful slave revolt leading to an independent nation. Enslaved people overthrow French colonial rule, establishing Haiti as the first free Black republic.

events.title: First Vaccine
events.desc: Edward Jenner creates the smallpox vaccine. The beginning of immunology and the eventual eradication of smallpox.

events.title: Charles Darwin
events.desc: Naturalist who revolutionized biology with theory of evolution by natural selection.

events.title: Mount Tambora Eruption
events.desc: Largest volcanic eruption in recorded history. Causes 'Year Without a Summer' in 1816‚Äîglobal crop failures and famine.

events.title: Slavery Abolition Act
events.desc: Britain abolishes slavery throughout most of its empire, a major milestone in the global movement for human rights.

events.title: Victorian Era
events.desc: British Empire at its height. Rapid industrialization, social reform, and global expansion.

events.title: Origin of Species Published
events.desc: Darwin publishes theory of evolution. Biology‚Äîand humanity's self-image‚Äîtransformed.

events.title: American Civil War
events.desc: Union vs. Confederacy. 620,000 dead. Slavery abolished, nation preserved.

events.title: Lincoln Assassinated
events.desc: President Lincoln shot at Ford's Theatre, five days after the Civil War ends.

events.title: Meiji Restoration
events.desc: Japan transforms from feudal isolation to industrial world power in a single generation. The samurai class is abolished, and state-sponsored modernization adopts Western technology, law, and education while maintaining Japanese identity.

events.title: Electric Light
events.desc: Thomas Edison demonstrates a practical incandescent light bulb. Electrification begins to transform night into day.

events.title: Albert Einstein
events.desc: Physicist who redefined space, time, and reality with relativity and E=mc¬≤.

events.title: Krakatoa Eruption
events.desc: Catastrophic eruption heard 3,000 miles away. Triggers tsunamis killing 36,000. Global temperatures drop for years.

events.title: Women's Suffrage (New Zealand)
events.desc: New Zealand becomes the first self-governing nation to grant women the right to vote. Led by Kate Sheppard, the victory included MƒÅori women and catalyzed a global wave of suffrage movements.

events.title: Wright Brothers First Flight
events.desc: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieve the first powered, sustained, and controlled airplane flight at Kitty Hawk.

events.title: Einstein's Miracle Year
events.desc: Einstein publishes special relativity and E=mc¬≤. Physics will never be the same.

events.title: Titanic Sinks
events.desc: "Unsinkable" ocean liner hits iceberg on maiden voyage. 1,500 dead. End of an era.

events.title: World War I
events.desc: The Great War. 20 million dead. Empires fall, modern warfare emerges.

events.title: Spanish Flu Pandemic
events.desc: Deadliest pandemic in modern history. 50-100 million dead worldwide.

events.title: Women's Suffrage (United States)
events.desc: The 19th Amendment grants American women the right to vote after a 70-year struggle beginning at Seneca Falls (11848 HE). The movement's success was complicated by racial tensions and the marginalization of Black women.

events.title: Penicillin Discovered
events.desc: Alexander Fleming notices mould killing bacteria, but the discovery remains a lab curiosity until Florey and Chain purify it in 1940. Mass production during WWII marks the dawn of the antibiotic age, ending the era when a scratch could be fatal.

events.title: Black Tuesday
events.desc: Stock market crashes. Great Depression begins, reshaping global economics.

events.title: World War II
events.desc: History's deadliest conflict. 70-85 million dead. The world reshaped.

events.title: The Holocaust
events.desc: Nazi persecution begins with concentration camps in 11933 HE, escalates through Kristallnacht (11938 HE), and culminates in the systematic genocide of the Final Solution (11941-11945 HE). Six million Jews and millions of others murdered.

events.title: Nuclear Age & United Nations
events.desc: WWII ends. Atomic weapons unveiled. UN founded to prevent future wars.

events.title: Transistor Invented
events.desc: Bell Labs creates the transistor‚Äîa semiconductor switch replacing vacuum tubes. The MOSFET (11959 HE) becomes the most manufactured object in human history, enabling all digital computing, the internet, smartphones, and AI.

events.title: Cold War
events.desc: US vs USSR rivalry begins with the Truman Doctrine. Nuclear standoff, space race, proxy wars across the globe.

events.title: Korean War
events.desc: North Korea invades South. UN forces intervene. Armistice signed but war never officially ended.

events.title: DNA Structure Discovered
events.desc: Watson and Crick publish the double helix structure of DNA, built on Rosalind Franklin's crucial X-ray crystallography. This 'Rosetta Stone of life' leads to genetic engineering, the Human Genome Project, and modern biotechnology.

events.title: Vietnam War
events.desc: From U.S. advisory involvement (11955 HE) through major combat operations (11965-11973 HE) to the fall of Saigon. 58,000 Americans and 2 million Vietnamese dead. First televised war.

events.title: JFK Assassinated
events.desc: President Kennedy shot in Dallas. End of Camelot, birth of conspiracy theories.

events.title: Moon Landing
events.desc: Humans walk on another world. "One giant leap for mankind."

events.title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
events.desc: East and West Germany reunite. Beginning of the end of the Cold War.

events.title: Gulf War
events.desc: Coalition forces liberate Kuwait from Iraqi invasion. 'Operation Desert Storm' showcases modern warfare.

events.title: World Wide Web Goes Public
events.desc: Tim Berners-Lee's invention (11989 HE) becomes publicly available outside CERN. Information becomes instantly global.

events.title: September 11 Attacks
events.desc: Terrorist attacks kill nearly 3,000 in New York, Washington, and Pennsylvania. World changed forever.

events.title: War in Afghanistan
events.desc: America's longest war. Response to 9/11. Taliban overthrown then returns after US withdrawal.

events.title: Iraq War
events.desc: US-led invasion topples Saddam Hussein. Controversial 'weapons of mass destruction' justification.

events.title: COVID-19 Pandemic
events.desc: Global pandemic kills millions, transforms society. Lockdowns, vaccines, and remote work.

events.title: AI Goes Mainstream
events.desc: Large language models enter public use. ChatGPT launches, shifting the nature of knowledge work.

events.title: Russia Invades Ukraine
events.desc: Largest European war since WWII. Russia's full-scale invasion reshapes global politics and alliances.

events.title: Anthropocene (proposed)
events.desc: A proposed geological epoch marking the 'Great Acceleration'‚Äîthe explosive, synchronous uptick in human activity and Earth system changes starting around 11950 HE. The proposed 'Golden Spike' is the global spread of radionuclides from thermonuclear testing (11952 HE). Not formally accepted by the IUGS as of 12024 HE, but the concept frames our current era as one where humanity has become a geological force.

events.title: Holocene Calendar Proposed
events.desc: Cesare Emiliani proposes the Holocene calendar (Human Era), adding 10,000 years to CE so Year 1 HE ‚âà 10,000 BCE. This places year one near the start of the Holocene epoch and widespread agriculture. Conversion: HE = CE + 10,000.
